image.legend: Friday is World AIDS Day to raise awareness about the deadly disease which was identified in the early 1980s

title: Israeli medical centers honor world AIDS day by illuminating buildings in red
metaTitle: Israeli medical centers honor world AIDS day by illuminating buildings in red
body:
Israel's largest medical centers will light up their buildings in red December 1 to mark World AID's Day to promote the global struggle against AIDS, in collaboration with the Organization for Life with HIV and Gilead Sciences, Inc according to The Jerusalem Post. 

Medical centers in Israel— Sourasky, Sheba, Hadassah-University and Rambam will illuminate their main buildings in red to honor the day.

The World Health Organization (WHO) and other health organizations, including the Health Ministry, have joined “90-90-90,” the international program to eradicate AIDS, according to which 90% of all HIV carriers in the world will be diagnosed; 90% of the carriers will receive drug treatment; and 90% of all carriers will reach undetectable status.

The chairman of the Organization for Life with HIV notes that “an undetectable AIDS carrier cannot infect anyone with the AIDS virus, can have sex without a condom with a single partner, and can bring healthy children into the world.”

According to a recent report by the United Nations (UN), more than 7 million people in South Africa are living with the virus.

The UN's general assembly is calling on countries across the world to ensure that at least 90% of people living with AIDS receive comprehensive prevention services by next year.

World AIDS Day was launched 31 years ago today, the first ever global health day.
excerpt: More than 7 million people in South Africa are living with the virus, according to a UN report
metaDescription: More than 7 million people in South Africa are living with the virus, according to a UN report

image.legend: Cette photo d'archive créée le 02 avril 2019 montre le Premier ministre israélien Benyamin Netanyahou (à gauche) et son principal rival aux élections législatives du 17 septembre Benny Gantz

title: Israel: Rival parties scramble to gather support for chance at forming gov't
metaTitle: Israel: Rival parties scramble to gather support for chance at forming gov't
body:
Israel's Likud party is racing to gather signatures from lawmakers in a bid to earn another chance at forming the next government, after kingmaker Avigdor Liberman said he would pledge support for both incumbent Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and the rivaling Blue & White leader, Benny Gantz. 

Blue & White has also begun collecting signatures from Israeli parliament (MK) members, according to local media reported Sunday. 

Liberman vowed to give Yisrael Beitenu's signatures to both the right-wing Likud and the centrist Blue & White upon their request, according to Ynet, as lawmakers are allowed to sign for multiple candidates.

Since Likud had already garnered support from 55 parliament members in the election, Liberman's eight could potentially lift Netanyahu over the 61-signature mark. Gantz's party would need the support of Arab lawmakers in order to reach the 61-majority coalition.  

A form was sent to each member of the right-wing bloc, requesting them to sign and submit a short statement backing Netanyahu by 9 AM Sunday, according to Hebrew media outlet reports.

While Israel's Attorney General Avichai Mandelblit ruled last week that Netanyahu could continue to serve as interim premier, it is unclear whether the president can hand him the mandate to form a government amid the indictment charges standing against him. 

Negotiating teams between the two parties are scheduled to meet Sunday afternoon, to discuss an offer that would allow Netanyahu to serve as PM for four months, after which he would step down and allow Gantz to take over.
excerpt: Negotiating teams between the two parties are scheduled to meet Sunday afternoon
metaDescription: Negotiating teams between the two parties are scheduled to meet Sunday afternoon

image.legend: A plane takes off behind the air traffic control tower at San Francisco International Airport in San Francisco, Tuesday, Nov. 26, 2019

title: US: South Dakota plane crash kills nine, injures three others
metaTitle: US: South Dakota plane crash kills nine, injures three
body:
An airplane in South Dakota crashed shortly after take-off, leaving nine people dead and injuring three others on Saturday while a winter storm warning was in effect, officials said. 

The Pilatus PC-12, a single-engine turboprop plane, crashed shortly after take-off approximately a mile from the Chamberlain airport, the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) said.

Among the dead were two children and the plane's pilot, Brule County state's attorney Theresa Maule Rossow said, adding that a total of 12 people had been on board.

The three survivors were taken to a hospital in Sioux Falls.

The flight left the airport just before noon local time, bound for Idaho Falls Regional Airport. 

South Dakota is located in the Northern Plains, a region facing blizzard conditions as a storm blows eastward across the US.

A winter storm warning remains in effect in Brule County until midday Sunday, the National Weather Service said, potentially including blowing snow that "could significantly reduce visibility."

"The men and women of law enforcement, first responders and medical professionals should be commended in their heroic actions to rescue the victims in extreme weather conditions," the state's attorney office said.
excerpt: Among the dead were two children and the plane's pilot
metaDescription: Among the dead were two children and the plane's pilot

image.legend: Blue and White party chairman Benny Gantz speaks at faction meeting at the Knesset, the Israeli parliament in Jerusalem, on November 11, 2019.

title: Israel: Gantz says 'no coalitions or opposition' when it comes to security
metaTitle: Israel: Gantz says 'no coalitions or opposition' when it comes to security
body:
Benny Gantz, chief of the Blue and White party and Netanyahu's arch-rival, pledged a united front on Saturday in a post on his Facebook page.

He said that despite all the internal struggles on the political scene, Israel stood united in the face of the outside security threats.

“The infiltration of a drone into Israeli airspace in the north and the ongoing weapons fire against residents of the south who are again forced into bomb shelters are very serious incidents,” he said.

Gantz added that there were no 'coalitions and opposition' when it came to keeping the Israeli citizens safe, and that Blue and White supported any responsible government action on these fronts.

On Friday, a drone crossed into the Israeli territory from Lebanon, quickly retreating back.

In a separate incident, Friday also saw another rocket attack on Israel from Gaza, prompting the IDF to respond with strikes against Hamas targets in the Strip.

The statement comes ahead of a key meeting between Likud and Blue and White negotiations teams on Sunday, brokered by Parliament Speaker Edlestein in a last-ditched coalition effort.

Blue and White members reportedly stayed off the Tel Aviv protests urging Netanyahu to resign to avoid angering Likud's leader.

The two sides will discuss a plan that will see Netanyahu sit as the Prime Minister for the next few months and then give the seat over to Blue and White, which would subsequently return it to Likud.

While some Israeli media reported that both Likud and Blue and White officials were untypically optimistic about the upcoming meetings, other reports suggest the two parties are collecting signatures in a bid to give their respective leaders another attempt to form a coalition.
excerpt: Statement comes ahead of key meeting between Blue and White and Likud negotiators for last-ditched talks
metaDescription: Statement comes ahead of key meeting between Blue and White and Likud negotiators for last-ditched talks

image.legend: Naftali Bennett et Benyamin Netanyahou

title: Israeli defense minister to tech experts: help Iranians to be heard
metaTitle: Israeli Defense Minister to tech experts: Help Iranians make their voice heard
body:
Interim Israeli Defense Minister Naftali Bennett came out on Saturday with a special address to the computer experts across the globe.

In a video posted on his Twitter and Facebook accounts, he ask that, Bennett urges IT experts to "help the long-suffering Iranian people gain open access to all social media," as they remain inaccessible in the Islamic Republic. 

A special message to help the Iranian people against their repressive regime:

קריאה מיוחדת לסייע לעם האיראני אל מול המשטר המדכא שלו: pic.twitter.com/0HI2IQ0EJf

— Naftali Bennett בנט (@naftalibennett) November 30, 2019

In the address, the freshly appointed defense minister referred to the recent protests in Iran over a surprise petrol price hike, which quickly escalated into anti-regime demonstrations.

Tehran responded with brute forces, unleashing a crackdown that claimed over 140 lives, according to Amnesty International, and while these figures are disputed in Tehran, the accounts on social media suggest some 400 have been killed.

During the unrest, the country was unplugged from the World Wide Web as Tehran shut down the Internet access in a bid to disrupt the protesters' ability to coordinate their actions and communicate to the outside world.

The recent unrest, as experts say, marked the first time an authoritarian government was able to stage a blackout of this scale, all but depriving some 80 million people off Internet access.

Iran's key strength in this respect is in in the infrastructure, with only two exchanges, or gateways, between the country's domestic net and the global web - and both are controlled by the government.
excerpt: Startup Nation's Defense Minister urges global talents to break through Iran's social media blackout
metaDescription: Startup Nation's Defense Minister urges global talents to break through Iran's social media blackout

image.legend: Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas, right, speaks with the French Minister of Economy, Industry and Digital Affairs Emmanuel Macron in the West Bank city of Ramallah. Monday, Sept. 7, 2015.

title: Palestinian president says 'dead end' in relations with Israel
metaTitle: Palestinian president says 'dead end' in relations with Israel
body:
Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas said on Saturday that the relations with Israel hit a 'dead end.'

According to the Palestinian news agency Wafa, Abbas also urged Europe to collectively recognize the independent Palestinian state along the pre-1967 lines, its capital in east Jerusalem.

This step, he said, was necessary to salvage the two-state solution.

The remarks were made during the PA president's meeting with Miguel Moratinos, Spanish diplomat who also serves as the UN High-Representative for the Alliance of Civilizations.

The meeting comes after the US announced that it would no longer view Israeli settlement activity as illegal under the international law.

According to State Secretary Pompeo, this policy shift did not amount to a ruling on the legality of any specific settlements, which was left to be established in Israeli courts.

The EU, a top aid provider for the Palestinian Authority, responded by saying that its own policy on the matter remained unchanged.

While 138 out of 193 UN members have recognized Palestine, only nine of those are EU members.

In 2014 Sweden became the first EU country to formally recognize Palestine, but a wholesale recognition by the whole bloc so far remains a questionable prospect.
excerpt: Abbas urged Europe to collectively recognize independent Palestine in response to new US settlements policy
metaDescription: Abbas urged Europe to collectively recognize independent Palestine in response to new US settlements policy

image.legend: IDF conducts special operation in the Aroub refugee camp near Hebron - 27 October 2019

title: West Bank: Rioter killed in clash with IDF near Hebron
metaTitle: West Bank: Rioter killed in clash with IDF near Hebron
body:
A Palestinian rioter was killed in a clash with Israel Defense Forces (IDF) in the vicinity of Hebron in the West Bank on Saturday.

According to the IDF, the troops spotted three suspects lobbing Molotov cocktails at an Israeli vehicle in Beit Awwa, to the west of Hebron.

The troops moved to thwart the attacks, opening fire and leaving one of the rioters dead. The deceased has been identified by Ramallah as 18-year-old Badawi Masalmeh, with his body reportedly taken by IDF. 

The other two were reportedly arrested and brought in for interrogation. 

Earlier in the week, in a break from routine, Palestinians held a West Bank-wide 'Day of Rage' protest on Tuesday.

The demonstration came in response to US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo's bombshell announcement of a shift in the US stance on the legality of Israeli settlements in the West Bank.
excerpt: IDF troops opened fire after firebombs were lobbed at an Israeli vehicle
metaDescription: IDF troops opened fire after firebombs were lobbed at an Israeli vehicle

image.legend: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu heads the weekly cabinet meeting at the Prime Minister's office in Jerusalem, Sunday, Nov. 24, 2019

title: Israel: Protesters in Tel Aviv rally, urging Netanyahu to resign
metaTitle: Israel: Protesters in Tel Aviv rally, urging Netanyahu to resign
body:
Some 10,000 people took to Habima Square in Tel Aviv Saturday to call on Israel's interim Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to resign in the wake of the indictments announced by the country's attorney general.

The rally was organized by an NGO called Movement for Quality Government in Israel, which earlier petitioned the Israeli High Court to force Netanyahu to tender his resignation.

The petition was dismissed, because Israeli law only clearly requires lawmakers and ministers to step down if facing charges, leaving the premier in unknown territory. 

Protesters chanted "Shame!" and raised signs urging the PM to leave his office.

Netanyahu is facing allegations of fraud, bribery and breach of trust in three cases, with Attorney General Avichai Mandelblit rolling out the indictment last Thursday.

The bombshell announcement sent shockwaves through the country, prompting a fiery response from Netanyahu that he later walked back on. 

It remains to be seen whether those shockwaves will help break Israel's political deadlock, with Likud and Blue & White negotiation teams set to meet on Sunday as part of a coalition effort brokered by the Speaker of Parliament Yuli Edelstein. 

According to Israeli media reports on Saturday, officials from the rivaling parties spoke with rare optimism ahead of their talks.
excerpt: Tale of Two Cities, Israeli-style, unravels as Jerusalem holds counter-rally in support of besieged PM
metaDescription: Tale of Two Cities, Israeli-style, unravels as Jerusalem holds counter-rally in support of besieged PM

image.legend: Dutch police block a shopping street after a stabbing incident in the center of The Hague, Netherlands, Friday, Nov. 29, 2019. Dutch police say multiple people have been injured in a stabbing incident in The Hague's main shopping street. (AP Photo/Phil Nijhuis)

title: Suspect arrested after three hurt in Dutch stabbing incident
metaTitle: Dutch police say several wounded in stabbing attack
body:
A suspect was arrested over the weekend after an intensive manhunt for the assailant in a stabbing attack in the Hague that wounded three in the city center on Black Friday. 

"Following the stab incident in Grote Marktstraat, a 35-year-old man has just been arrested in the center of The Hague. The man has no fixed place of residence," police said on Twitter.

The 35-year-old suspect was detained in the city's center a day after shoppers were thrown into a panic during their race for bargains at Grote Marktstraat, a popular consumer destination lined with department stores and cafes, 

"Stabbing incident with several wounded at the Grote Marktstraat in The Hague. Emergency services are on site," the city's police said on Twitter.

The condition of the victims remains unclear as police searched for a "slightly dark-skinned man" aged between 40 and 50 wearing a black top, scarf and grey jogging bottoms.

Dutch police say that they are still investigating the motive behind the violent assault, as Dutch news agency ANP quoted sources saying there was "no talk of a terror motive," thought there was no immediate confirmation

The incident came just hours after a deadly terror attack claimed the lives of two victims and wounded several more on London Bridge.
excerpt: Manhunt was launched after violent attack at Grote Marktstraat, a popular consumer destination
metaDescription: Manhunt was launched after violent attack at Grote Marktstraat, a popular consumer destination

image.legend: Members of the Joint List, in front from left to right, Osama Saadi, Ayman Odeh, Ahmad Tibi and Mansour Abbas arrive for a consulting meeting with Israeli President Reuven Rivlin, in Jerusalem, Sunday, Sept. 22, 2019

title: Israel: Arab lawmaker Tibi heckled, assaulted by right-wing activists
metaTitle: Israel: Arab lawmaker Tibi heckled, assaulted by right-wing activists
body:
Ahme Tibi, a lawmaker and a leader with the predominantly Arab Joint List alliance in Israel's parliament, was heckled and assaulted by right-wing activists ahead of an event on Saturday.

In a video re-tweeted by Tibi, a woman can be seen trying to hit him with an Israeli flag as he was entering a site in the city of Ramat Hasharon.

According to the Israeli police, a woman was detained for questioning after she allegedly threw sand and branches at the lawmaker. Later, she was released.

Right-wing activists also tried to prevent Tibi from entering the venue and shouted abuse at him, calling the lawmaker "terrorist" and "murderer."

Following the attacks, the lawmaker blamed the incident on interim PM Netanyahu's firebrand statements on Arab lawmakers, calling them nothing short of incitement.

He said that if a minority government aided by Joint List had been formed, Israeli right-wingers would have responded with deadly violence.   

He also accused Netanyahu of incitement against the late Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, who was assassinated in 1995 by a right-wing extremist over amid his push for peace with the Palestinians.  

 “It’s worked out once for Netanyahu," Tibi said. "We’re easier targets than a serving prime minister.”
excerpt: If an Arab-backed minority gov't had been formed, right-winders would have resorted to murder, Tibi says
metaDescription: If an Arab-backed minority gov't had been formed, right-winders would have resorted to murder, Tibi says

image.legend: Police officers seal an entrance to a apartment building in the town of Durres, western Albania, Saturday, Nov 30, 2019.

title: Death toll in Albania earthquake hits 51 as search for survivors wraps up
metaTitle: Death toll in Albania earthquake hits 51 as search for survivors wraps up
body:
The death toll in the 6.4 magnitude earthquake that hit Albania earlier this week stood at 51 as the authorities called off the search for the victims on Saturday.

The latest victim of the quake that left about 5,000 people homeless, a 20-year-old woman, died in a hospital Saturday, the country's defense ministry said.

"Rescue operations have ended," Prime Minister Edi Rama told a cabinet meeting while struggling to hold back tears as he read the victims' names.

Entire families were crushed in their homes while they were sleeping, forcing relatives and neighbors to watch in agony as rescue teams pulled bodies from the ruins this week.

The damage was the worst in Durres, on the Adriatic coast, and the nearby town of Thumane, where scores of people were trapped beneath the wreckage of apartment buildings and hotels.

About 900 people were injured in the earthquake, the strongest to hit Albania in decades, of whom 41 are still hospitalized, the authorities said.

Nearly 2,500 people from the worst-hit areas have been moved into hotels or other buildings.
excerpt: Around 900 injured in worst earthquake to hit Albania in decades
metaDescription: Around 900 injured in worst earthquake to hit Albania in decades

image.legend: Mayor of Tel Aviv Ron Huldai poses for a photograph at a launch event for the new public transportation buses which will run on Shabbat, starting this weekend.

title: Israel: Tel Aviv Shabbat buses massively popular on second weekend after launch
metaTitle: Israel: Tel Aviv Shabbat buses see massive demand on second weekend
body:
Tel Aviv's public Shabbat buses program remained a massive hit with the riders on the second weekend since its inception, its fleet expanded in the face of last week's soaring demand.

With no figures released yet, Ynet cited the project's manager as saying that the buses were full on Friday and Saturday despite the expansion.

This weekend, 52-seat buses were used to service the six routes covered by the "We move on weekends" initiative alongside the 19-seat minibuses that were already available to Tel Avivis on Shabbat.

The frequency of the service was also increased, with buses arriving every twenty minutes, not twice an hour.

Last weekend, some 10,000 riders made use of the service, with the decision to expand the fleet made just three hours after the launch of the initiative as the demand soared through the roof.

Packed to the brim, mini-buses had to skip stops with passengers waiting for a ride.

Seeing the massive success of the initiative, additional cities moved to announce launches of similar Shabbat service.   

The Tel Aviv Shabbat bus service was launched despite heavy protests from the Orthodox communities, which saw it as a violation of an agreement dating back to Israel's inception -- and an affront to Shabbat as such.

The six routes currently trailing through Tel Aviv steer away from religious neighborhoods.

Saturday saw massive rallies condemning the expansion of the program in Bnei Brak, a town near Tel Aviv, where Orthodox protesters blocked a road.
excerpt: This weekend, 52-seat buses joined the fleet of minibuses on the six routes to cover for soaring demand
metaDescription: SEO

image.legend: Security force and civilians gather near the burned Iranian consulate in Najaf, Iraq, Thursday, Nov. 28, 2019.

title: Iraqi PM files resignation letter after uptick in violence
metaTitle: Iraqis keep up anti-regime protests despite PM's vow to quit
body:
Iraq's besieged Prime Minister Adel Abdul Mahdi submitted his resignation to parliament on Saturday following an uptick in violence amid the deadly crackdown on protests.

The cabinet approved his resignation in an emergency session that was hailed prior to the letter being submitted to the lawmakers.

According to the Associated Press, the Iraqi parliament is expected to either immediately approve the resignation or hold a vote on it Sunday.  

On Friday, Mahdi announced he was planning to resign the following day, as protests continued in his birthplace of Nasiriyah, in Iraq's south.

Despite the announcement, anti-government demonstrations continued across the country with protesters demanding that "all corrupted people" step down. 

Saturday also saw renewed protests in Iraq's south, despite the PM following through on his promise.

According to Reuters citing an unverified video sent in to the agency, the protesters set the entrance to a shrine in the southern city of Najaf on fire. Earlier, demonstrators burned the Iranian consulate in the city, accusing Iraq's neighbor of propping up the Baghdad government.

The rising deaths have sparked global criticism, with the United Nations saying the deaths "cannot be tolerated" and the French foreign ministry saying it "strongly condemns the excessive and disproportionate use of force against protesters."
excerpt: The renewed rallies came despite a bloody crackdown by security forces that has left over 40 dead
metaDescription: Their renewed rallies came despite a bloody crackdown by security forces that has left over 40 dead

image.legend: Forensic officers attend the scene in central London, Saturday, Nov. 30, 2019, after an attack on London Bridge on Friday.

title: Islamic State claims responsibility for deadly London stabbing
metaTitle: UK to review early release rules after ex-terror convict stabs two to death
body:
In a statement released by its Amaq news agency, the Islamic State (IS) terror group claimed responsibility Saturday for the stabbing attack in London that left two people dead.

Though the group failed to offer any evidence of its involvement, it said the stabbing had been carried out by one of its members in response to a call for violence against the countries that are part of the anti-ISIS coalition led by the US. 

Earlier in the day, the UK authorities vowed to do a "full review" of the early prisoner release program after an ex-convict stabbed at least two to death on Friday. 

The suspected attacker, Usman Khan, who was shot dead by police during the assault, had previously been convicted on terrorism charges.

He was conditionally released from jail last December after serving less than half of his 16-year sentence for terrorism.

The Parole Board said it had no involvement in his release and that it appeared to have happened automatically, under a legal procedure that provides for the early release of convicts if they follow certain probationary terms and fit the required criteria.

The Friday attack, which also left three wounded, has triggered a public debate on the practice, with Prime Minister Johnson weighing in on Saturday.

"I think that the practice of automatic, early release where you cut a sentence in half and let really serious, violent offenders out early simply isn't working," he said, as cited by Reuters.

Johnson, who hopes to win a majority in a December 12 election and take Britain of the European Union, praised the emergency services and the public for their response.
excerpt: Attacker known to authorities, released early after conviction on terror charges
metaDescription: PM Johnson says deadly London Bridge stabbing shows early release policy 'simply isn't working'

image.legend: A demonstrator chants slogans while holding up an Iranian national flag during a pro-government rally denouncing last week’s violent protests over a fuel price hike in Tehran, Iran, Monday, Nov. 25, 2019.

title: Iran pushes back against 'exaggerated' protest death toll
metaTitle: Iran pushes back against 'exaggerated' protest death toll
body:
Iran on Saturday rejected international condemnation for deaths resulting from nation-wide protests over fuel prices, disputing a report published by a human rights group who claimed over 160 demonstrators were killed.

Officials in Iran have yet to say how many people died in the ensuing violence that saw banks, petrol pumps and police stations set on fire.

London-based human rights group Amnesty International said in a tweet on Friday that the crackdown claimed the lives of 161 demonstrators, citing what it called "credible reports."

Since 15 November #Iran's security forces have brutally killed 161 protesters. Their human stories are now emerging. We remember them & will continue to seek justice for them & their families. pic.twitter.com/SnprPcaKcp

— Amnesty International (@amnesty) November 29, 2019

But Iran's deputy interior minister, Jamal Orf, disputed such figures.

"Statistics by international organisations on those killed in the recent incidents are not credible," he was quoted as saying by state news agency IRNA. Orf accused the sources that reported the figures of "exaggerating" them.

The governments of the United States, France and Germany have condemned Iran over the bloodshed.

The unrest broke out on November 15, hours after it was announced that the price of gas would rise to 15,000 rials per litre (12 US cents) from 10,000 for the first 60 litres, and to 30,000 rials for any extra fuel bought after that each month.
excerpt: The governments of the United States, France and Germany have condemned Iran over the bloodshed
metaDescription: The governments of the United States, France and Germany have condemned Iran over the bloodshed

image.legend: Pope Francis reportedly joked with Mozambican President Filipe Nyusi last September that he would visit Mozambique in 2019 "if I'm still alive"

title: Persecuted Catholic refugees risk arrest to get glimpse of Pope Francis in Thailand
metaTitle: Persecuted Catholic refugees risk arrest to get glimpse of Pope Francis in Thailand
body:
Scores of Vietnamese Catholic refugees registered to attend a mass by Pope Francis when he arrives in Thailand on Wednesday, despite the risk of arrest and deportation by local authorities. 

The four-day jaunt is the Pope's first trip to Thailand, where about 1,400 Vietnamese Christians and ethnic minorities have settled, many fearing religious persecution in communist Vietnam.

Many live in fear of arrest and long detention in immigration centers since the Thai government has not signed on to UN conventions protecting refugees. And some have waited years to be resettled in a third country as they scrape by on under-the-table jobs for a few dollars a day. 

The chance to glimpse the Pope at the Thursday mass is a welcome respite. 

"It's difficult to describe the feeling... It is a great honour for us to see him," said 34-year-old Ko Sa, sitting on a mattress on the floor of a rented house where she lives with eight other people.

"When I think of how miserable my life is here I just cry," added Ko Sa, who works as a cleaner for $5 a day. 

As a Catholic and a member of the vulnerable K'Ho ethnic minority, she feared repercussions from authorities in the one-party state where religion is tightly controlled. 

The communist government in Vietnam has long had an uneasy relationship with organised religion, with Catholics making up seven percent of the population.  

Today all religions in Buddhist-majority Vietnam are controlled by the state and any practitioners operating without official registration could face jail time. 

Francis will hold two masses and meet with the Catholic community and top officials before jetting on Saturday to Japan, where he will visit Nagasaki and Hiroshima, the sites of the world's only atomic attacks. 

Some 50,000 people from Thailand and all over Southeast Asia are signed up for the Pope's first mass on November 21 in Bangkok.
excerpt: Some have waited years to be resettled in a third country as they scrape by on dollars a day
metaDescription: Some have waited years to be resettled in a third country as they scrape by on dollars a day

image.legend: شعار شركة التواصل الاجتماعي العملاقة Facebook

title: Facebook implements new 'fake news' warning in Singapore
metaTitle: Facebook implements new 'fake news' warning in Singapore
body:
The government of Singapore on Saturday successfully forced social media giant Facebook to publish a correction on a user's post warning his content contains "false information."

The move marks the first time a tech giant has complied with the city-state's law against misinformation.

Authorities had ordered Facebook to correct a post promoting an article on a fringe news site containing "scurrilous accusations" of election rigging, ramping up their use of a controversial law against misinformation.

The law gives ministers powers to tell platforms to put warnings next to posts they deem false, but that activists fear could be used to curb free speech.

A post by Alex Tan -- who runs anti-government website the States Times Review -- had a correction notice placed below it after a government request, Facebook confirmed.

On Thursday authorities had ordered Tan to put up a correction next to his November 23 post on elections. But Tan -- who is based overseas -- refused, saying he is an Australian citizen and would not comply with requests from a "foreign government".

But after authorities ordered Facebook to put a correction next to the post, the social media giant said it had complied.

The item now appears with a label below it, stating: "Facebook is legally required to tell you that the Singapore government says this post has false information".

It also contains a link to the government's own fact-checking website.

"As required by Singapore law, Facebook applied a label to these posts, which were determined by the Singapore Government to contain false information," said a Facebook spokesperson on Saturday.
excerpt: A new law in Singapore allows the government to put warnings next to posts they deem false
metaDescription: A new law in Singapore allows the government to put warnings next to posts they deem false

image.legend: Supporters of the of the far-right Alternative fuer Deutschland (AfD) celebrate after first results in Erfurt, Germany, Sunday, Oct. 27, 2019

title: Germany's far-right AfD party elects new leadership
metaTitle: Radicals rise as Germany's far-right AfD party looks to elect new leaders
body:
Germany's far-right AfD (Alternative for Germany) party elected its new leadership on Saturday, placing its bets on a duo of a radical and a moderate.

Former house-painter Tino Chrupalla, 44, replaces 78-year-old Alexander Gauland to join incumbent co-leader Joerg Meuthen, 58, at the top of the party.

Chrupalla, who met US President Donald Trump's ex-advisor Steve Bannon earlier this year, is not a member of the party's radical Fluegel faction.

Speaking ahead of the vote, he said that his alliance with Meuthen would set the party up for a historic moment, "with representatives from east and west and a leadership duo in which both academics and non-academics can identify".

Last month, he was booed in parliament after accusing Chancellor Angela Merkel of treating her voters as "underlings" with "micro-aggressions against everything German".

He has also called the "Islamization of the West" a "reality", saying that one could qualify it as a replacement of the population.

His main challenger will be fellow AfD MP Gottfried Curio, a fiery orator whose parliamentary speeches have made him a far-right social media star.

The AfD started out as a eurosceptic party but became increasingly anti-migrant and opposed to Merkel after the chancellor welcomed around one million asylum-seekers in 2015 and 2016.

Mainstream parties have refused to work with the AfD and therefore prevented it from holding executive power on a national or regional level.
excerpt: The AfD, which was only established six years ago, is riven with personal and ideological rivalries
metaDescription: The AfD, which was only established six years ago, is riven with personal and ideological rivalries

image.legend: Police forensic officers work where a man was shot dead by police on London Bridge following an incident in London, Friday, Nov. 29, 2019.

title: London knife attacker identified as former terrorism convict
metaTitle: London knife attacker identified as former terrorism convict
body:
A man suspected of stabbing two people to death in a terror attack on London Bridge was a former prisoner convicted for terrorism offences and released last year, police said Saturday.

Police identified the man, who was shot dead by officers after Friday's attack, as 28-year-old Usman Khan, saying they were not actively seeking any other suspects in relation to the incident.

"This individual was known to authorities, having been convicted in 2012 for terrorism offences," Assistant Commissioner Neil Basu said in a statement, and had been released on probation. 

CNN reported that Khan, along with eight others, had been arrested in 2010 as part of a major counterterrorism operation involving an "al-Queda inspired plot" to blow up the UK Stock Exchange. 

Court documents show that Khan, originally from Pakistan, later confessed that he was involved in fundraising and recruiting for a terrorist military training facility on land in Kashmir that was owned by his family. 

Three more people were wounded in the daylight stabbing spree which revived memories of a three-man attack on London Bridge two years ago that killed eight. One of the surviving victims was said to be in critical but stable condition. 

Basu said that Khan had been living in the Staffordshire region of central England and officers were searching an address in that area. British media reported that Khan may have had ties to Islamic fundamentalist groups and was known to UK intelligence services.  

"The circumstances, as we currently understand them, are that the attacker attended an event earlier on Friday afternoon at Fishmonger's Hall called 'Learning Together'," the statement said.

"We believe that the attack began inside before he left the building and proceeded onto London Bridge, where he was detained and subsequently confronted and shot by armed officers."

Fishmonger's Hall is a historic listed building on the north side of the bridge in the center of the capital.
excerpt: Usman Khan, 28, was shot dead by officers after Friday's attack that claimed the lives of two people
metaDescription: Usman Khan, 28, was shot dead by officers after Friday's attack that claimed the lives of two people

image.legend: Rockets are launched from Gaza Strip to Israel, Tuesday, Nov. 12, 2019.

title: IDF strikes Hamas position in retaliation for Gaza rocket strike in south
metaTitle: IDF: Rocket alert siren sounds in Israel's south
body:
The IDF said on Friday that one projectile fired from the Gaza Strip was launched towards Israel, setting off a rocket alert in the country's south. 

Less than an hour after the incident, the IDF said it launched an airstrike at a Hamas military position. A subsequent second rocket sounded in the city off Ashkelon but the IDF later said it was a false alarm. 

No damage to infrastructure or injuries have been reported. Initial reports suggest that the projectile was allowed to land in an open area. 

It remains unclear who is behind the incident. Israel holds the terror organization Hamas responsible for all aggression originating from the coastal enclave. 

Earlier on Friday, a Palestinian teenager was killed by Israeli fire near the Gaza border, the Hamas-run Health Ministry said in a statement. 

Four others were also reportedly wounded. Weekly protests, known as the "Great March of Return," along the Gaza border fence have subsided in recent weeks after nearly 18 months of demonstrations. 

Meanwhile, the Lebanese daily Al-Akhbar reported Friday that talks over the past two days have resumed between Hamas and Israel through Egyptian, Qatari and UN mediators over a long-term truce agreement, which also cover the issue of a prisoners swap deal. 

According to the report, in return for long-term calm in Gaza, construction of new facilities are being considered for Palestinians, such as a Turkish-funded desalination plant, a new US-funded hospital, and a new power station.
excerpt: No damage to infrastructure or injuries have been reported.
metaDescription: This is a developing story

image.legend: Mexico President Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador says 50 billion pesos could be saved through the government's strategy to combat fuel theft

title: Mexico warns will not allow US military operations against cartels
metaTitle: Mexico warns will not allow US military operations against cartels
body:
The government of Mexico is warning its neighbor to the north that it will not allow the American military to conduct cross-border armed operations against drug cartels on its sovereign territory. 

The comments came after US President Donald Trump vowed to designate Mexican drug cartels as terrorist groups while speaking to disgraced former talk show host Bill O'Reilly earlier this week. 

President Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador said in response that "Armed foreigners cannot intervene in our territory. We will not allow that." 

Mexico has a history of resenting Washington's armed interventions in Latin American countries, especially prevalent in the last century. 

Obrador was quick to add that he considered any such operations unlikely, saying there was "great cooperation" between the neighbors and that Trump had always treated him "respectfully."

The US president has been talking tough on the powerful drug cartels since one was allegedly responsible for the massacre of nine women and children from a US-Mexican Mormon community in northern Mexico on November 4.

Mexico has registered more than 250,000 murders since deploying the army into the streets, including an all-time high of 33,743 last year -- a record that looks set to be broken again this year.
excerpt: Mexico has a history of resenting Washington's armed interventions in Latin American countries
metaDescription: Mexico has a history of resenting Washington's armed interventions in Latin American countries

image.legend: Protester women wave their national flags in front of the fence of Gaza Strip border with Israel, marking first anniversary of Gaza border protests east of Gaza City, Saturday, March 30, 2019.

title: Palestinian teen killed by IDF fire near Gaza border fence: health ministry
metaTitle: Palestinian killed by IDF fire near Gaza border fence: health ministry
body:
A Palestinian teenager was reportedly shot and killed by IDF troops near the Gaza border on Friday.  

The Health Ministry in the Hamas-run enclave said that Fahd al-Astal, 16, died after being shot in the stomach east of Khan Yunis in southern Gaza.

Four other Palestinians were wounded on Friday, the Gaza Health Ministry added. It remains unclear if the shootings are connected.

The circumstances of the shooting were unclear, with weekly border protests officially cancelled. The Israeli army said it was looking into the incident.
excerpt: Four other Palestinians were wounded on Friday, the Gaza Health Ministry
metaDescription: Four other Palestinians were wounded on Friday, the Gaza Health Ministry

image.legend: Armed police at the scene of an incident on London Bridge in central London following a police incident, Friday, Nov. 29, 2019

title: Two dead in London Bridge 'terrorist incident,' suspect killed
metaTitle: UK: Police say 'incident' on London Bridge after reports of shots fired
body:
Two members of the public were killed when a man wearing a suspected hoax explosive device went on a stabbing rampage before being shot dead on London Bridge, British media said on Friday.

The Metropolitan Police called the deadly assault a "terrorist incident."

The man believed to be responsible for the violent attack was initially taken into custody after being shot, but succumbed to his wounds while being treated at the scene. 

Medical professionals have not disclosed the condition of the survivors. Police said that the suspect had also been wearing a "hoax explosive device” around his chest. 

"I'm being kept updated on the incident at London Bridge and want to thank the police and all emergency services for their immediate response," UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson said in a statement. 

Police were initially called to the scene of an "incident" on London Bridge after receiving reports of gunfire at the site.

A BBC reporter on the bridge at the time said he saw what appeared to be a fight between a group of men, heard two shots and saw a man "prone" on the ground.

The incident happened shortly after 2:00 pm (local time) on the north side of the bridge. People in the area were quickly ushered away from the scene, images on social media indicated.

London Ambulance Service confirmed it had crews on the scene.

One eyewitness told the BBC she and other people in the area rushed into a restaurant on the bridge and were told by staff to take cover.

I’m near London Bridge, looks like a bad incident - people running, police yelling “Keep moving”, lots of emergency services, area cordoned off. Stay safe everyone pic.twitter.com/1nF2YNUQTN

— Owen Jones🌹 (@OwenJones84) November 29, 2019

London Bridge was the scene of a terrorist attack in 2017 when two men inspired by the ISIS global terror organization used their vehicle to run over pedestrians. 

Khuram Butt, 27, and 30-year-old Rachid Redouane managed to kill two people with their car before stabbing several people to death in nearby Borough Market. 

Their rampage was subsequently ended after police managed to shoot and kill the assailants.
excerpt: Scotland Yard added that they were treating the incident 'as though it is terror-related'
metaDescription: This is a developing story

image.legend: FILE - Iraqi Prime Minister Adel Abdul-Mahdi looks around during a welcome ceremony in Ankara, Turkey, Wednesday, May 15, 2019

title: Iraqi PM to submit resignation after top cleric calls for cabinet change
metaTitle: Iraqi PM announces resignation after Ayatollah Sistani calls for cabinet change
body:
Iraqi Prime Minister Adel Abdel Mahdi said Friday he would submit his resignation to parliament, hours after the country's top Shiite cleric called for a cabinet change amid deadly protests.

"I will submit to the esteemed parliament a formal letter requesting my resignation from the premiership," Abdel Mahdi said in a statement.

Mahdi said he made the decision after listening "with great concern" to a sermon delivered by Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani, touted as the spiritual leader of Iraqi Shia Muslims, with the senior cleric urging parliament to "reconsider its options” over who should lead the country. 

“We call upon the House of Representatives from which this current government emerged to reconsider its options in that regard,” al-Sistani said in the statement. 

The sudden turnaround came after nearly two months of bloody protests against the ruling class that have left more than 400 dead and 15,000 wounded and was met with cheers from protesters in Baghdad's iconic Tahrir (Liberation) Square.

Abdul-Mahdi had served as a prime minister just over a year was after being appointed as a consensus candidate between political blocs in Iraq's parliament.
excerpt: Mahdi said he made the decision after listening to a sermon delivered Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani
metaDescription: More to follow

image.legend: German Chancellor Angela Merkel delivers a speech during a meeting of the German federal parliament, Bundestag, at the Reichstag building in Berlin, Germany, Wednesday, Nov. 27, 2019

title: Chancellor Merkel to pay first ever visit to Auschwitz
metaTitle: Chancellor Merkel to pay first ever visit to Auschwitz
body:
German Chancellor Angela Merkel will pay her first visit to Auschwitz-Birkenau next Friday, her spokeswoman said, ahead of the 75th anniversary commemorations for the liberation of the Nazi death camp.

Merkel will be only the third chancellor after Helmut Schmidt and Helmut Kohl to travel to the camp installed by the Nazis in then occupied Poland during World War II.

At Auschwitz, she will hold a minute of silence at the Black Wall, where inmates were executed by Third Reich soldiers.

She will then make a speech at the Birkenau part of the camp, which was where the Nazis erected most of the machinery of mass extermination, including the gas chambers.

Polish Prime Minister Mateusz Morawiecki will attend while the chancellor will also lay a wreath.

Merkel's visit comes at the invitation of the Auschwitz-Birkenau Foundation, which is commemorating 10 years of its founding.

On the eve of her trip, she and premiers of Germany's 16 states, are due to confirm 60 million euros ($66 million) in funding for the foundation.

With one million Jews killed there between 1940 to 1945, the camp has become a symbol of Adolf Hitler's genocide of European Jews.

More than 100,000 other people also perished there, including non-Jewish Poles, Roma, Soviet prisoners of war and anti-Nazi resistance fighters.

Russian soldiers liberated Auschwitz on January 27, 1945.
excerpt: German leader expected to hold minute of silence at the Black Wall and deliver speech at Birkenau
metaDescription: German leader expected to hold minute of silence at the Black Wall and deliver speech at Birkenau
